data.title: Musings on Buffalo Fish, and Other Uses of “Buffalo”
data.meta_description: What comes to mind when you see the word “buffalo”? Is it the town in New York? Or maybe it’s the large, shaggy bison that roam the lands of Yellowstone National Park? Or perhaps you think of the…
data.text:
What comes to mind when you see the word “buffalo”? Is it the town in New York? Or maybe it’s the large, shaggy bison that roam the lands of Yellowstone National Park? Or perhaps you think of the large bovines in Africa?

Yes, all of those are named buffalo (although bison are, technically, entirely different). But there’s also another buffalo: the buffalo fish.

And the buffalo fish has an unusual backstory to its name.

The story starts with a French genius at (no joke) Transylvania University in the early 1800s.

Hello, Constantine Samuel Rafinesque-Schmaltz

In 1783, a man named Constantine Samuel Rafinesque-Schmaltz was born in the Ottoman Empire, near Constantinople. He grew up in Marseilles, France, where he taught himself Greek and Latin. He never attended a formal university, but taught himself botany and zoology.
